{"step_by_step_thinking": "Based on the description of the lesions as brown and greasy appearing, and the fact that the patient is 77 years old, the most likely diagnosis is seborrheic keratosis. Seborrheic keratosis is a common benign skin growth that typically appears in older individuals. It is characterized by brown or black lesions that have a waxy or greasy appearance. Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that can present as a pigmented lesion, but it is less likely in this case as the description does not mention any concerning features such as asymmetry, irregular borders, or color variation. Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by dark, thickened patches of skin, typically in the folds and creases of the body, and is often associated with insulin resistance or obesity. Erythema nodosum is a type of skin inflammation that presents as tender, red nodules, usually on the shins, and is typically associated with underlying systemic conditions such as infections or autoimmune diseases.", "answer_choice": "B. Seborrheic keratosis"}
